advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> SEEQUA AD (JUN. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60, to show that the BIT-60 is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>UK advert from Personal Computer World magazine, October 1983</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> A computer that, for the first time, works with you rather than just for you. Hardware and Software co-ordinating perfectly, Apricot arrives complete and ready to work.<br> The MicroScreen on the keyboard, unique to Apricot, performs a variety of practical functions as a calculator, calendar, time display, and as a window on the screen. Most signifIcantly the MicroScreen prompts and assists the user by presenting simple options whilst running applications.<br> Incorporating the very latest advances in computer technology, Apricot uses 31/2" pocket-size diskettes. Secure and compact, yet offering increased storage capacity.<br> As you'd expect with a 4th generation system, Apricot offers true 16-bit processing, multi-processor architecture and 256k RAM as standard. <br><br> With Pulsar 16-bit business software and compatibility with the best selling ACT Sirius 1 and IBM PC, Apricot already has the largest available software library. <br><br> Apricot includes over £750 of software­ - SuperCalc spreadsheet, business and communications software - to ensure that your system is immediately effective. And because executives are not office bound, Apricot offers portability, a further feature aimed at improving efficiency.<br> Powerful sleek and sophisticated and all at an amazing 4th generation price.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Intellivision video games. Realism goes past fiction"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEO-GEO ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://spoonman.roarvgm.com/neogeo/" target="_blank">SpoonMan's Neo-Geo page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The TO7 from Thomson has everything needed to fill the empty cells"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST SDK-85 AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the Intel logo. Does Intel copies the Apple logo or vice versa?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #2 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The columbia MPC is shipped with fully suported software that will save you $3,000. Included is the entire self-teaching Perfect Software family: Perfect Writer, a word processor; Perfect Speller, a 50,000 word dictionnary; Perfect Filer, a data base manager; and Perfect Calc, a financial calculation system.<br><br> In addition, you get MS-DOS, CP/M-86, Macro/86 assembler, BASICA, Asynchronous communication support, Diagnostics and the Columbia Tutor program...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first sentence of this advert is:<br> <i>The new Commodore 64 is the most powerful personal computer available to the businessman.</i><br> Which wasn't totally true, even totally false.<br><br> The picture is also totally unrealistic. Each detail sounds false.<br> The C64 never was a business system, but a perfect home computer. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT APR. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DUTCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Richard de Keijzer</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"This flexibly expandable computer grows by the increase of business activities and the rising requirements."<br><br> A reliable office computer, which can flexibly adapt to the business work, as it is essential for the office to execute resulting works promptly, correctly, and precisely.<br> A user-friendly conceived EDP-system like the MZ-3541 is essential, particularly for small to medium sized companies.<br> The MZ-3541 contributes for a substantial increase of the productivity in the office by the assumption of routine works. SHARP has designed the new MZ-3541 in such a way that it can be used for the most diverse resulting office works. And because multiple peripheral devices are available, the system can grow dynamically with the business activities.<br><br> The MZ-3541 is the result of Sharp's extensive market study and ergonomics studies. The free mobile keyboard makes data input and the operation easier and allows for spatial conditions an adapted installation of the system possible.<br> Sharp's MZ-3541 - the complete system for the business data processing. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #5 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #6</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, July 1982 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANCO BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The Personal Computer MZ-811 is a class of itself. Its infinite applications mark it." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1983 <br><br> Advert said <br><br><font color="#666666"> Simple Isn't it?. The COMPAQ portable computer can do what the IBM Personal Computer does. To go.<br><br> It runs all the popular programs written for the IBM. It works for the same printers ans other peripherals. It even accepts the same optional expansion electronics that give it additional capabilities and fonctionality.<br><br> There's really only one big difference. The COMPAQ computer is designed to travel.<br> Carry the COMPAQ computer from office to office. Carry it home on the weekend. Or take it on business trips...</font></blockquote>

computer.colors: Palette: 16.7 millionOn screen: 256 in normal modes, 262144 in HAM-8
computer.coprocessor: AGA based chipset: 8374 Alice (memory controller and blitter), 4203 Lisa (video control chip), 8364 Paula (sound & I/O), 391563-01 Akiko (I/O controller)
computer.description:
In a last ditch attempt to get a foothold in the lucrative console market Commodore launched the Amiga CD32. After their previous effort with the C64 GS failed and the strange decision to advertise the Amiga 600 as a games machine that could be used as a computer it was vital that the CD32 succeeded.
The CD32 is notable for being the first 32 bit CD-ROM based console ever released (the PlayStation wasn't released until the next year). It was based on the Amiga 1200 hardware which now had a new chip named Akiko that acted as a CD-ROM controller and I/O chip.
Initially the system was quite successful and managed to gain more than a 50% share of the CD-ROM based market in the U.K., where it outsold better known systems such as Sega's Mega CD and even the PC CD-ROM. Software for the CD32 was a bit of a disappointment though, mainly consisting of ports of old Amiga software with the odd video thrown in along with the obligatory CD music tracks.
Unfortunately for Commodore their financial problems had begun to take hold by this point. The U.S. government passed a ruling that banned Commodore from importing goods into the country as they owed $10million from a patent infringement lawsuit. With the financial situation rapidly getting worse and unable to sell the CD32 in the American market, Commodore filed for bankruptcy at the end of April 1994. The unsold CD32s were seized by the government of the Philippines as payment owed by Commodore for the use of a factory.
computer.name: Amiga CD32
computer.ports: serial port, expansion interface, 2x RCA audio, composite video out, RF out, keyboard interface, 2x Atari controller ports
